container.name: Recalling
container.p: Recalling its resolution 2015/10 of 10 June 2015, in which it endorsed the 2020 World Population and Housing Census Programme and urged Member States to conduct at least one population and housing census under the Programme, as well as its earlier resolutions endorsing previous decennial programmes,

container.name: Recognizing
container.p:
Recognizing population and housing censuses as a key primary source of disaggregated data needed for formulating, implementing and monitoring policies and programmes aimed at achieving inclusive socioeconomic development and environmental sustainability, in line with national, regional and international development commitments, and taking into account the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development,
General Assembly resolution 70/1.

container.name: Acknowledging
container.p: Acknowledging the commendable efforts of Member States in conducting population and housing censuses as part of the 2020 World Population and Housing Census Programme, despite the challenges posed by the coronavirus disease (COVID‑19) pandemic,

container.name: Recognizing
container.p: Recognizing the evolving landscape of census methodologies, including the rise of Internet-first, multi-mode approaches, georeferencing and increased use of administrative data,

container.name: Recognizing and commending
container.p: Recognizing and commending the significant progress made by Member States in the timely dissemination of census data during the 2020 round, which saw a notable speed of data dissemination following census enumeration,

container.name: Recognizing
container.p: Recognizing the centrality of population and housing censuses in population data systems, and the importance of data integration for enhancing cost-effectiveness, reducing respondent burden and generating rich, granular and timely data,

container.name: Recalling
container.p: Recalling its resolution 2006/6 of 24 July 2006, General Assembly resolution 68/261 of 29 January 2014, and General Assembly resolution 71/313 of 6 July 2017,

content.p: Endorses the 2030 World Population and Housing Census Programme, which comprises a number of activities aimed at ensuring that Member States conduct a population and housing census during the period from 2025 to 2034 and complementarily promote the continuous production of population and socioeconomic statistics at the small area level through the strengthening of administrative registers, surveys and other administrative and alternative data sources, and calls for fully fledged support for the Programme;

Recommends that Member States consider the fourth revision of the Principles and Recommendations for Population and Housing Censuses as the international standard for conducting population and housing censuses and for concepts, definitions and classifications on population and related statistics, to promote integration across data sources and statistical domains and to enhance data comparability within and across countries;

Urges Member States to conduct at least one population and housing census or otherwise produce population and socioeconomic statistics at the small area level under the 2030 World Population and Housing Census Programme, taking into account, as appropriate, the fourth revision of the Principles and Recommendations and other related international and regional recommendations, giving particular attention to advance planning, cost efficiency, coverage and the timely dissemination of, and easy access to census results for all, in order to inform decisions and facilitate the effective implementation of development plans and programmes;

Underscores the need for countries to set quality standards for the conduct and evaluation of population and housing censuses in order to uphold the integrity, reliability, accuracy and value of the population and housing census results, in line with the fourth revision of the Principles and Recommendations and taking into full account the United Nations Statistical Quality Assurance Framework, other quality frameworks, including national quality frameworks, standards and tools as well as the Fundamental Principles of Official Statistics;
General Assembly resolution 68/261.

Invites Member States to consider georeferencing their censuses, allowing aggregation to the lowest appropriate geographical level, dissemination of geocoded census data, as well as enabling the integration of geospatial information, census data and other data sources, while ensuring data confidentiality;

Encourages Member States to enhance their exploration and use of administrative data sources to support census operations and to consider the establishment of national statistical population registers; the establishment of such registers should be undertaken only in full compliance with their national development plans and priorities and in accordance with the provisions of the Fundamental Principles of Official Statistics, including the requirement to protect the confidentiality and privacy of individual records, and under clear and unambiguous legal provisions which include permission to exploit the national statistical population register solely for statistical purposes in line with national rules and regulations;
Official Records of the Economic and Social Council, 2022, Supplement No. 4 (E/2022/24), chap. I, sect. C, decision 53/107, subpara. (d).

Requests the Secretary-General to prepare or update international statistical standards, methods and guidelines to facilitate the planning and implementation of the 2030 round of population and housing censuses, and to translate these publications into the official languages of the United Nations to promote wider accessibility;

Also requests the Secretary-General to provide technical assistance to national statistical offices, upon their request, including through regional and subregional activities, and taking into account the different levels of development of Member States, to facilitate the exchange of experiences and lessons learned, and to strengthen national capacity to implement the 2030 World Population and Housing Census Programme;

Further requests the Secretary-General to develop platforms for exchanging knowledge, national experiences, practices and lessons learned in conducting population and housing censuses, including in the utilization of administrative sources;
Requests the Secretary-General to strengthen coordination and cooperation among partners and relevant stakeholders to assist Member States, upon their request, in implementing the Programme;
Also requests the Secretary-General to regularly report to the Statistical Commission on the implementation of the Programme.
